positions.title: Web Development Engineer
positions.description: Amazon Stores, those brand microsites you see such as https://www.amazon.com/lego or https://amazon.com/oxo or (as of just recently) https://www.amazon.com/apple

positions.title: Sr. Software Development Engineer - Front-end
positions.description:
We have a monolith serving both API and HTML, and what I'm doing here at OfferUp is teasing that behemoth apart, with an all-new service dedicated to HTML that calls our APIs. The monolith is in Django, the new service is Node/React.

I'm going way beyond my job description here, but but somebody has to do it. I'd rather be crafting microinteractions and pixel polishing UI implementation, but instead I'm often doing service owner stuff like making sure our EC2 cluster is healthy. I'd never even logged into AWS before this job, now I'm pretty comfortable with multiple AWS products.

First phase of the new web experience rolls out by end of Q1, look for it at offerup.com in a desktop or mobile browser.
…
see more

positions.title: Sr. Software Engineer
positions.description: Coming into this role, I'd used Angular but not React, so I had to ramp up quick on isomorphic React/Redux on Node/Express. Sorry (especially to former Google coworkers like Jen Bourey) but having used them both I definitely prefer React. I know they aren't quite the same, React does less than Angular, but for the simple task of dumping data into templates this stack shines.

Sharing economy meets third party logistics, i.e. warehouse space. #b2b #airbnbforwarehouses

Rails/Postgres web stack, which is mostly what I worked on, plus a little Android development. Things I first used here (and liked): FontAwesome, Bootstrap, Adobe XD. Things I first used here and hated (but convinced the team to abandon): HAML. Things I first used here and hated but couldn't do anything about: Github for code reviews, CoffeeScript.

positions.title: Google
positions.description: In the cloud org, working on the unified developer console (https://console.developers.google.com/).

positions.title:
Title
Senior Software Engineer
positions.description: In the cloud org, working on the unified developer console (https://console.developers.google.com/).

positions.title:
Title
Software Engineer
positions.description:
I'm on the DFP (Doubleclick for Publishers) team. That's the in-house Google product at google.com/dfp, not the acquired product at google.com/doubleclick/publishers/dart.html. It's a bit confusing. The product I work on is intended to replace the one we acquired.

I primarily do GWT development, which is the Google Web Toolkit. While I'm not a fan of transforming Java to JavaScript, I will say that you can't just have a bunch of unstructured JavaScript and expect a project of any size to work. So GWT gives you structure and patterns and a basic skeleton to hang client-side code on. Plus lots of other benefits like i18n and CSS class obfuscation and server-side testability of code, if testing is something you're into.
…

positions.title: Web Development Engineer
positions.description:
When I'm not writing JavaScript or Perl Mason or Python or Ruby or CSS, I can usually be found listening to my deskside turntable, or up on the 40th floor of the Columbia Center, at Starbucks, trying to order bizarre things like a "Double Tall Happy Meal" or a "Nonfat Alligator Machiatto (two pumps of alligator)".

Some things I wrote or had a significant hand in developing:

Greasemonkey scripts
Popover (DIV overlay) library, used across all of Amazon.com (with alpha PNGs even in IE6)
Throttling proxy server written in Twisted Python
Many JavaScript components, including drag and drop table columns, image magnifier, slideshow, slider controls, ajax form posting
Prototyped all sorts of concepts using JavaScript and Rails
Mac geekery such as a Phone Tool dashboard widget and contributions to the Amazon TextMate bundle
…

positions.title: Mega Extreme Web Developer
positions.description:
The usual ASPX, HTML, CSS, JavaScript, XSLT kinda stuff, plus more recently, Ruby on Rails. I came into this role with expert level knowledge of the front-end aspects of .NET, i.e. getting web controls to play nice with web standards, as well as world-class CSS skills. I mean I'm one of the first official entries in the CSS Zen Garden for god's sakes. One important thing I think I've learned here is JavaScript. So many web devs (myself included) assume they basically know it already because they studied computer science and they already know C++ and Java, but that's just not the case. It's a really powerful and interesting language, but you have to actually spend some time to learn it. If someone claims to know JavaScript just ask them how variable scoping works... it's nothing like C and if they don't know they haven't learned JavaScript yet.
…
see more

positions.title: Web Developer
positions.description: ASP.NET, SQL Server, AJAX. Kelly Smith is a righteous dude, but the company just wasn't a good fit for me. I wrote their Frame Shop, an interactive feature for choosing print size, frame, and matting. It was a lot of fun because it involved server-side image compositing (to scale) as well as ajax. It's served as a good demo in various job interviews.

positions.title: Web Developer
positions.description:
ASP.NET. This is where I learned ASP.NET, thanks to Kevin Mayer for giving me the opportunity to jump into a brand new (to me) technology. I also discovered that working from home sucks, it's lonely and depressing, so I moved on. I also did some "web production" work, i.e. "here's a Word doc and Photoshop comp, make it a webpage." That kind of work would have been so much easier if I'd had MangleBracket back then. That's right, MangleBracket. Check it out at manglebracket.com.

positions.title: Web Developer
positions.description: PHP, MySQL. This was my "pre .net" web development phase, when I hated Microsoft and would only use open source. I still hate Microsoft of course, but ASP.NET ain't so bad. All I really remember about this summer job was that I made $12 an hour, and the boss drove a cool black Lexus IS-300 and his brother smoked a lot of weed.

given.text: Many developers can code a solution. John, however, can see a feature in three dimensions. He turns it over in his hands, considers all its possibilities, then writes code that accomplishes more than you thought could be done when you wrote the spec. Want a webdev? I'm sure you can find one somewhere. Want a ninja? Talk to John

John worked on many web projects with me at Ashbury Designs. He is amazing with CSS. He was so reliable and would work through any problems we encountered. He just never gave up. It is a great quality to have in a worker and I really appreciated his dedication to getting jobs done on time. We worked over the phone or email a lot and he seemed to understand what I wanted even before I finished my sentence.
…
See more

As the former manager for John, I must say that for the $12 and hour John was awesome. His skills really speak for themselves. I am sure he has continued to become proficient and successful in his career. Good Luck John!
John is not only great at beef hoarding, but in hoarding all kinds of meats and food-stuffs that will survive throughout the ages. He has developed a way to store CornNuts in bulk. It's great.

John's strength was his excellent judgment in tackling engineering problems. He would intelligently weigh in all factors in his implementation decisions (from game play to testability). This allowed him to accomplish much more than his peers. His ability to take a vague set of specifications and implement a clean solution that exceeded the requirements was invaluable to us. I'm confident John will excel in any engineering career he chooses.
…
See more
“John is a great all around developer and particularly fast at complex client-side work though his abilities extend far beyond that arena. Great guy to work with and would hire again.”
John is a great all around developer and particularly fast and complex client work though his abilities extend far beyond that arena. Great guy to work with and would hire again.

received.text: To be honest, when I first got to know Brent I thought he was too "soft" to be an effective manager, but I've since discovered that he exemplifies the ideal management style. Consider this: He's wicked smart so he always knows what he's talking about. And what does he choose to do with that technical confidence? He peers himself with his subordinates, not in that "I'm not really your manager, I'm your buddy" sort of way, but in an approachable charismatic sort of way that gives me, the software developer, courage to innovate free from VP distraction. In any arena, people that can have the center without having to take the center are extremely valuable, and Brent is such a character.

Josh is social glue. He makes the days fun, and makes the team gel. At Digital Railroad, I liked almost everybody (save one, which I won't mention here). But it was Josh Weltman and my "boss" Ben Maldonado who improved my work moral on a daily basis. The fact that Josh was able to do so while not even being on my team is a testament to his sunshine powers. I don't know much about is official work duties, but I do know that I'd sacrifice a significant amount of monetary reward for the chance to work with him again.
